channel.title: Global News Podcast
channel.description: The day’s top stories from BBC News. Delivered twice a day on weekdays, daily at weekends
channel.itunes:summary: The day’s top stories from BBC News. Delivered twice a day on weekdays, daily at weekends
channel.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Presidential debate: Trump and Biden in chaotic encounter
item.description: President Trump and Joe Biden have held a bitter and angry White House debate. They argued fiercely over Coronavirus, the economy, healthcare and far-Right extremism. Also, senior figures in India's governing BJP found not guilty of inciting Hindu extremists to demolish mosque, and why some experts think the world needs to drastically change its diet.
item.itunes:subtitle: President Trump and Joe Biden have held a bitter and angry White House debate
item.itunes:summary: President Trump and Joe Biden have held a bitter and angry White House debate. They argued fiercely over Coronavirus, the economy, healthcare and far-Right extremism. Also, senior figures in India's governing BJP found not guilty of inciting Hindu extremists to demolish mosque, and why some experts think the world needs to drastically change its diet.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: US presidential debate
item.description: Donald Trump and Joe Biden clash in a chaotic and combative debate. We hear from Cleveland, Ohio, where this first election debate is taking place and have analysis from our reality check correspondent. Also: the young people born and raised in Italy who are fighting for their right to citizenship, and could keeping exotic pets lead to their extinction?
item.itunes:subtitle: Donald Trump and Joe Biden clash in a chaotic and combative debate
item.itunes:summary: Donald Trump and Joe Biden clash in a chaotic and combative debate. We hear from Cleveland, Ohio, where this first election debate is taking place and have analysis from our reality check correspondent. Also: the young people born and raised in Italy who are fighting for their right to citizenship, and could keeping exotic pets lead to their extinction?
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: UN holds emergency meeting about Azerbaijan and Armenia
item.description: Dozens have been killed as the violence between the countries escalates. Also: a horrific rape case in India has once again raised questions about women's rights and the caste system, and more people are keeping exotic reptiles as pets than previously thought...but could it lead to their extinction?
item.itunes:subtitle: Dozens have been killed as the violence between the countries escalates
item.itunes:summary: Dozens have been killed as the violence between the countries escalates. Also: a horrific rape case in India has once again raised questions about women's rights and the caste system, and more people are keeping exotic reptiles as pets than previously thought...but could it lead to their extinction?
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Global coronavirus deaths pass one million
item.description: The US, Brazil and India account for nearly half the total. Experts say the true figure is probably much higher. Also: Amnesty International says it has been forced to stop work in India, could emergency teams soon be using jetpacks to get to patients, and how the fashion world is adapting designs for the Covid era.
item.itunes:subtitle: The US, Brazil and India account for nearly half the total
item.itunes:summary: The US, Brazil and India account for nearly half the total. Experts say the true figure is probably much higher. Also: Amnesty International says it has been forced to stop work in India, could emergency teams soon be using jetpacks to get to patients, and how the fashion world is adapting designs for the Covid era.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: WHO to give cheap, quick coronavirus tests to poorer countries
item.description: They cost 5 dollars and give results in less than 30 minutes. Also: fighting between Azerbaijan and Armenia escalates; and a pigeon that went missing 24 years ago in New Zealand has finally come home.
item.itunes:subtitle: They cost 5 dollars and give results in less than 30 minutes
item.itunes:summary: They cost 5 dollars and give results in less than 30 minutes. Also: fighting between Azerbaijan and Armenia escalates; and a pigeon that went missing 24 years ago in New Zealand has finally come home.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: India passes six million coronavirus cases
item.description: It comes on the day eighty-two thousand new cases were reported. We look at where the pandemic is heading there. Also: why the English football league system could be facing financial collapse, and we hear from the veteran naturalist and now Instagram king, David Attenborough.
item.itunes:subtitle: It comes on the day eighty-two thousand new cases were reported
item.itunes:summary: It comes on the day eighty-two thousand new cases were reported. We look at where the pandemic is heading there. Also: why the English football league system could be facing financial collapse, and we hear from the veteran naturalist and now Instagram king, David Attenborough.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: New York Times says Donald Trump 'paid $750 in federal income taxes' in 2016
item.description: The newspaper says it has obtained tax records for the US president over two decades. Mr Trump denied the report as "totally fake news". Also: Armenia and Azerbaijan battle over disputed region.
item.itunes:subtitle: The Trump Organization rejected the allegations
item.itunes:summary: The newspaper says it has obtained tax records for the US president over two decades. Mr Trump denied the report as "totally fake news". Also: Armenia and Azerbaijan battle over disputed region.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Trump picks Amy Coney Barrett for Supreme Court
item.description: The nomination of a conservative judge paves the way for a bitter Senate fight as an election looms. Also: Madrid at "serious risk" without virus lockdown, and NASA is working with a cosmetics company on space station commercialization.
item.itunes:subtitle: If confirmed by senators, she will replace Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg who died recently
item.itunes:summary: The nomination of a conservative judge paves the way for a bitter Senate fight as an election looms. Also: Madrid at "serious risk" without virus lockdown, and NASA is working with a cosmetics company on space station commercialization.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Trump 'to pick Amy Coney Barrett' for Supreme Court
item.description: The judge and former law professor from Indiana is a favourite of social conservatives. Also: Paris stabbing attack 'an act of terrorism', and polio vaccination campaigners in Pakistan battle misinformation and distrust.
item.itunes:subtitle: She would replace the late liberal Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
item.itunes:summary: The judge and former law professor from Indiana is a favourite of social conservatives. Also: Paris stabbing attack 'an act of terrorism', and polio vaccination campaigners in Pakistan battle misinformation and distrust.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Paris attack: Two hurt, two arrested near former Charlie Hebdo office
item.description: One of the arrested suspects was found with blood on his clothing, according to a police source. Also: Farmers in India are blocking roads and railways using tractors and livestock during protests and the elite rat saving lives by sniffing out landmines
item.itunes:subtitle: A blade - described as a machete or a meat cleaver - was recovered at the scene.
item.itunes:summary: One of the arrested suspects was found with blood on his clothing, according to a police source. Also: Farmers in India are blocking roads and railways using tractors and livestock during protests and the elite rat saving lives by sniffing out landmines
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Vatican cardinal resigns unexpectedly
item.description: Cardinal Becciu became involved in a controversial deal to buy a luxury building in London. He denies any wrongdoing. Also: the US Republican leader has said there will be an "orderly" post presidential election transition, and how lockdown birds sang to a different note.
item.itunes:subtitle: The cardinal will keep his title despite the resignation.
item.itunes:summary: Cardinal Becciu became involved in a controversial deal to buy a luxury building in London. He denies any wrongdoing. Also: the US Republican leader has said there will be an "orderly" post presidential election transition, and how lockdown birds sang to a different note.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: UK chancellor announces new job support scheme
item.description: It begins in November and means the government will pay part of workers’ wages who have lost hours because of the coronavirus pandemic. Also: South Korea has condemned North Korea's killing of a civilian official who was apparently trying to defect as unforgivable, and we look at some of the contenders for the Mercury music prize.
item.itunes:subtitle: It begins in November and means the government will pay part of workers’ wages
item.itunes:summary: It begins in November and means the government will pay part of workers’ wages who have lost hours because of the coronavirus pandemic. Also: South Korea has condemned North Korea's killing of a civilian official who was apparently trying to defect as unforgivable, and we look at some of the contenders for the Mercury music prize.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Protests in Kentucky after Grand Jury decision
item.description: Grand jury decides not to charge police officers over fatal shooting of Breonna Taylor; mass protests in Belarus after Alexander Lukashenko is secretly sworn in for another term as president; and why Africa is seeing a sustained fall in the number of new coronavirus infections.
item.itunes:subtitle: Grand jury decides not to charge police officers over fatal shooting of Breonna Taylor
item.itunes:summary: Grand jury decides not to charge police officers over fatal shooting of Breonna Taylor; mass protests in Belarus after Alexander Lukashenko is secretly sworn in for another term as president; and why Africa is seeing a sustained fall in the number of new coronavirus infections.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: EU proposes new migration rules
item.description: All countries will have to take in refugees or sponsor the return of those refused asylum. Also: the Russian opposition politician, Alexei Navalny, has been discharged from hospital where he was being treated for Novichok nerve agent poisoning, and a Grammy-nominated singer is building a high-tech city in Senegal with its own cryptocurrency.
item.itunes:subtitle: All countries will have to take in refugees or sponsor the return of those refused asylum
item.itunes:summary: All countries will have to take in refugees or sponsor the return of those refused asylum. Also: the Russian opposition politician, Alexei Navalny, has been discharged from hospital where he was being treated for Novichok nerve agent poisoning, and a Grammy-nominated singer is building a high-tech city in Senegal with its own cryptocurrency.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Coronavirus: US death toll passes 200,000
item.description: President Trump's administration has been repeatedly criticised over its handling of the virus. In March, President Trump said if deaths were between 100,000 and 200,000, the country would have done a "very good job". Also: police forces around the world seize more than 6.5 million dollars in cash and virtual currencies, as well as drugs and guns in a co-ordinated raid on dark web marketplaces, and NASA announces a plan for the first woman on the Moon by 2024 as a staging post for the first human mission to Mars.
item.itunes:subtitle: The US accounts for around 20% of world’s total fatalities
item.itunes:summary: President Trump's administration has been repeatedly criticised over its handling of the virus. In March, President Trump said if deaths were between 100,000 and 200,000, the country would have done a "very good job". Also: police forces around the world seize more than 6.5 million dollars in cash and virtual currencies, as well as drugs and guns in a co-ordinated raid on dark web marketplaces, and NASA announces a plan for the first woman on the Moon by 2024 as a staging post for the first human mission to Mars.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: China tycoon critical of Xi gets 18 years in jail
item.description: Ren Zhiqiang went missing earlier this year after writing an essay said to be critical of President Xi. Also: Arctic sea-ice shrinks to a near record low extent, and the Italian university accused of fixing a language exam for the footballer Luis Suarez.
item.itunes:subtitle: Ren Zhiqiang went missing in March after writing an essay criticising President Xi
item.itunes:summary: Ren Zhiqiang went missing earlier this year after writing an essay said to be critical of President Xi. Also: Arctic sea-ice shrinks to a near record low extent, and the Italian university accused of fixing a language exam for the footballer Luis Suarez.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: 10pm curfew for English pubs and restaurants
item.description: Order comes as scientists increase the UK's coronavirus alert level. Also: Ruth Bader Ginsburg's last dictated message to her grand-daughter, Twitter's apparent racial bias and China's Hollywood propaganda videos.
item.itunes:subtitle: Order comes as scientists increase the UK's coronavirus alert level
item.itunes:summary: Order comes as scientists increase the UK's coronavirus alert level. Also: Ruth Bader Ginsburg's last dictated message to her grand-daughter, Twitter's apparent racial bias and China's Hollywood propaganda videos.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: 'Be brave', Svetlana Tikhanovskaya tells the EU
item.description: The Belarusian opposition leader wants the EU to impose sanctions against President Lukashenko and senior officials. Also: a global poll shows the world is split on the urgency of tackling climate change, and the big winners at the virtual Emmys.
item.itunes:subtitle: The Belarusian opposition leader wants EU sanctions against President Lukashenko
item.itunes:summary: The Belarusian opposition leader wants the EU to impose sanctions against President Lukashenko and senior officials. Also: a global poll shows the world is split on the urgency of tackling climate change, and the big winners at the virtual Emmys.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Leaks show scale of bank laundering
item.description: BBC investigation reveals how criminals were helped to move dirty money around the world. Also: reprieve for We Chat after US judge blocks Trump ban order, hundreds protest against Madrid lockdowns and Gore-Tex creator dies.
item.itunes:subtitle: BBC investigation reveals how criminals were helped to move dirty money around the world
item.itunes:summary: BBC investigation reveals how criminals were helped to move dirty money around the world. Also: reprieve for We Chat after US judge blocks Trump ban order, hundreds protest against Madrid lockdowns and Gore-Tex creator dies.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: When will the next US Supreme Court judge be nominated?
item.description: Washington is split over who will take the position, following Ruth Bader Ginsberg's death. Also: a former British diplomat is being investigated for allegedly spying on the EU for China, and frozen ground in Siberia is thawing and contributing to climate change.
item.itunes:subtitle: Washington is split over who'll take the position, following Ruth Bader Ginsberg's death
item.itunes:summary: Washington is split over who will take the position, following Ruth Bader Ginsberg's death. Also: a former British diplomat is being investigated for allegedly spying on the EU for China, and frozen ground in Siberia is thawing and contributing to climate change.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: WHO warns pandemic is not going away anytime soon
item.description: It comes as Israel returns to a nationwide lockdown and several countries tighten restrictions. Also: the US will ban downloads of the Chinese-owned apps, TikTok and WeChat, from Sunday, and seven footprints found in an Arabian desert may change the timeline of human history.
item.itunes:subtitle: It comes as Israel becomes the first country to return to a nationwide lockdown
item.itunes:summary: It comes as Israel returns to a nationwide lockdown and several countries tighten restrictions. Also: the US will ban downloads of the Chinese-owned apps, TikTok and WeChat, from Sunday, and seven footprints found in an Arabian desert may change the timeline of human history.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Israel marks Jewish New Year with 2nd Covid-19 lockdown
item.description: Israel is trying to tackle the surge in coronavirus cases, with a new three-week lockdown. Also: China military drill as US envoy visits Taiwan, and an alligator on gas snaps up Ig Nobel prize.
item.itunes:subtitle: Rosh Hashanah is traditionally a time for family get-togethers
item.itunes:summary: Israel is trying to tackle the surge in coronavirus cases, with a new three-week lockdown. Also: China military drill as US envoy visits Taiwan, and an alligator on gas snaps up Ig Nobel prize.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Global coronavirus cases top 30 million
item.description: The 30 million landmark comes as the World Health Organisation warns about the situation in Europe. Also: Fires devastate the world's largest wetland, and hear about the incredible life of the female secret agent who is said to have inspired the creator of James Bond.
item.itunes:subtitle: The coronavirus pandemic is particularly resurgent across Europe
item.itunes:summary: The 30 million landmark comes as the World Health Organisation warns about the situation in Europe. Also: Fires devastate the world's largest wetland, and hear about the incredible life of the female secret agent who is said to have inspired the creator of James Bond.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: China defends its mass 're-education' policies in Xinjiang
item.description: China says millions of workers --mostly Muslim Uighurs -- have been retrained in centres, which the US has likened to concentration camps. Also: WHO warns of "very serious situation" regarding Covid-19 in Europe, and what are the bizarre new stunts included in the latest Guinness World Records?
item.itunes:subtitle: A new report says 1.3 million people annually have received such training since 2014
item.itunes:summary: China says millions of workers --mostly Muslim Uighurs -- have been retrained in centres, which the US has likened to concentration camps. Also: WHO warns of "very serious situation" regarding Covid-19 in Europe, and what are the bizarre new stunts included in the latest Guinness World Records?
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Lamine Diack: Former head of World Athletics found guilty of corruption and jailed
item.description: The ex-head of athletics’ governing body was convicted of accepting bribes from athletes suspected of doping to cover up test results and letting them continue competing, including in the 2012 London Olympics. Also: Venezuela says the UN report which accuses its government of systematic violations to suppress political opponents is riddled with falsehoods, and an artificial intelligence-powered ship aiming to recreate a historic voyage from 400 years ago.
item.itunes:subtitle: The 87-year-old faced corruption charges linked to the Russian doping scandal
item.itunes:summary: The ex-head of athletics’ governing body was convicted of accepting bribes from athletes suspected of doping to cover up test results and letting them continue competing, including in the 2012 London Olympics. Also: Venezuela says the UN report which accuses its government of systematic violations to suppress political opponents is riddled with falsehoods, and an artificial intelligence-powered ship aiming to recreate a historic voyage from 400 years ago.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Venezuela: UN investigators accuse government of crimes against humanity
item.description: UN Human Rights Council looked into cases of killings, torture, and disappearances. Investigators say President Maduro and other top officials were implicated. Also, top intergovernmental group says global economy is doing better than expected, and should we all learn to appreciate statistics more ?
item.itunes:subtitle: UN Human Rights Council looked into cases of killings, torture, and disappearances
item.itunes:summary: UN Human Rights Council looked into cases of killings, torture, and disappearances. Investigators say President Maduro and other top officials were implicated. Also, top intergovernmental group says global economy is doing better than expected, and should we all learn to appreciate statistics more ?
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Israel signs diplomatic accord with UAE and Bahrain
item.description: It was signed at the White House with President Trump. He hailed the dawn of a new Middle East. Also: India passes five million coronavirus cases - we hear how families are suffering, and the TV ad which overshadowed a reality star appearance on ‘Dancing With the Stars’.
item.itunes:subtitle: It was signed at the White House with President Trump
item.itunes:summary: It was signed at the White House with President Trump. He hailed the dawn of a new Middle East. Also: India passes five million coronavirus cases - we hear how families are suffering, and the TV ad which overshadowed a reality star appearance on ‘Dancing With the Stars’.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Poisoned Navalny ‘will return to Russia’
item.description: The Russian opposition leader posts on social media that he's getting better. A photo showed him sitting up in his Berlin hospital bed, surrounded by his wife and children. Also: new figures suggest China's economy is recovering from the pandemic, and hip hop fans prepare to bid on memorabilia at Sotheby’s in New York.
item.itunes:subtitle: The Russian opposition leader posts on social media that he's getting better
item.itunes:summary: The Russian opposition leader posts on social media that he's getting better. A photo showed him sitting up in his Berlin hospital bed, surrounded by his wife and children. Also: new figures suggest China's economy is recovering from the pandemic, and hip hop fans prepare to bid on memorabilia at Sotheby’s in New York.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Evidence that Venus may harbour life
item.description: Scientists discover a gas in the atmosphere of Venus that may have been produced by living organisms. Also: Climate change takes centre stage in the US presidential race, and the enduring appeal of Pinocchio, the tale of the wooden puppet who wants to be a real boy.
item.itunes:subtitle: Scientists discover gas that may have been produced by living organisms
item.itunes:summary: Scientists discover a gas in the atmosphere of Venus that may have been produced by living organisms. Also: Climate change takes centre stage in the US presidential race, and the enduring appeal of Pinocchio, the tale of the wooden puppet who wants to be a real boy.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Belarus: UN calls for investigation of torture allegations
item.description: Belarusians protesting against President Alexander Lukashenko have allegedly been kidnapped and beaten by security forces. Also, Yoshihide Suga is expected to be sworn in as Japan’s next prime minister, after being selected as leader of the governing Liberal Democratic Party. And one of the most powerful men in football – Nasser Al Khelaifi – goes on trial over the sale of World Cup television rights.
item.itunes:subtitle: Security forces have been seen beating protesters
item.itunes:summary: Belarusians protesting against President Alexander Lukashenko have allegedly been kidnapped and beaten by security forces. Also, Yoshihide Suga is expected to be sworn in as Japan’s next prime minister, after being selected as leader of the governing Liberal Democratic Party. And one of the most powerful men in football – Nasser Al Khelaifi – goes on trial over the sale of World Cup television rights.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Belarus: Thousands rally against President Lukashenko
item.description: More than 100,000 anti-government protestors took to the streets of Minsk. Also: Israel announces a new national lockdown to contain a surge in coronavirus infections, and a permanent migrant reception centre is to be built on the Greek island of Lesbos.
item.itunes:subtitle: More than 100,000 anti-government protestors took to the streets of Minsk
item.itunes:summary: More than 100,000 anti-government protestors took to the streets of Minsk. Also: Israel announces a new national lockdown to contain a surge in coronavirus infections, and a permanent migrant reception centre is to be built on the Greek island of Lesbos.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Afghan government urges ceasefire with Taliban
item.description: At peace talks in Qatar, the Afghan delegation said war had no winners. Also: Pompeo in Cyprus warns US "deeply concerned" over Turkey energy search, and British designer, Sir Terence Conran, dies aged 88.
item.itunes:subtitle: The Taliban have dismissed the ceasefire demand
item.itunes:summary: At peace talks in Qatar, the Afghan delegation said war had no winners. Also: Pompeo in Cyprus warns US "deeply concerned" over Turkey energy search, and British designer, Sir Terence Conran, dies aged 88.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Bahrain says it is normalising ties with Israel
item.description: Bahrain is only the fourth Arab country in the Middle East to recognise Israel. Also: dozens of people missing in Oregon fires; migrants and Greek islanders protest over new camp.
item.itunes:subtitle: The Israeli PM called it a new era of peace
item.itunes:summary: Bahrain is only the fourth Arab country in the Middle East to recognise Israel. Also: dozens of people missing in Oregon fires; migrants and Greek islanders protest over new camp.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Moria: European Commission says migrant camp will be rebuilt after huge fire
item.description: EC's Vice-president says burnt-out camp to be replaced by modern facility on same site. Residents of Moria camp have staged protest calling for right to leave island of Lesbos. Also, Rio Tinto's boss to quit over company's destruction of Aboriginal sacred sites, and we meet a man who reads out confessions of dead people at their own funerals.
item.itunes:subtitle: EC's Vice-president says burnt-out camp to be replaced by modern facility on same site
item.itunes:summary: EC's Vice-president says burnt-out camp to be replaced by modern facility on same site. Residents of Moria camp have staged protest calling for right to leave island of Lesbos. Also, Rio Tinto's boss to quit over company's destruction of Aboriginal sacred sites, and we meet a man who reads out confessions of dead people at their own funerals.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: EU ultimatum to UK over Brexit talks
item.description: The UK is told to drop plans to rewrite the withdrawal agreement by end of the month or risk scuppering the trade deal. Also: Microsoft says Russia, China and Iran hackers are targeting Trump and Biden, and the British actress Dame Diana Rigg dies aged 82.
item.itunes:subtitle: The European Union has said the British proposals have "seriously damaged trust"
item.itunes:summary: The UK is told to drop plans to rewrite the withdrawal agreement by end of the month or risk scuppering the trade deal. Also: Microsoft says Russia, China and Iran hackers are targeting Trump and Biden, and the British actress Dame Diana Rigg dies aged 82.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Greek ships to help shelter 13,000 migrants after camp burned
item.description: A blaze engulfed Moria camp on Tuesday night, then another wiped out any remaining tents on Wednesday. Also: The opposition politician in Belarus told she would be deported ‘alive or in bits’ and backlash in China after attempts to bring in couples counselling before marriage.
item.itunes:subtitle: Greece is sending three ships to help house thousands sleeping rough on Lesbos
item.itunes:summary: A blaze engulfed Moria camp on Tuesday night, then another wiped out any remaining tents on Wednesday. Also: The opposition politician in Belarus told she would be deported ‘alive or in bits’ and backlash in China after attempts to bring in couples counselling before marriage.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Trump accused of deliberately misleading US on Covid-19
item.description: The remark is contained in a book by the journalist, Bob Woodward, who broke the Watergate scandal. Also: Greek fire sparks race to shelter 13,000 migrants, and scientists develop a technique to spot fake Scotch whisky without opening the bottle.
item.itunes:subtitle: The US president said he had wanted to avoid causing public panic over the outbreak
item.itunes:summary: The remark is contained in a book by the journalist, Bob Woodward, who broke the Watergate scandal. Also: Greek fire sparks race to shelter 13,000 migrants, and scientists develop a technique to spot fake Scotch whisky without opening the bottle.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Fire destroys Greece's largest migrant camp
item.description: A huge fire has ravaged the Moria facility on the island of Lesbos. Thousands of migrants have been left homeless. Also, efforts to make the Oscars more diverse, and how one man developed a friendship with an octopus.
item.itunes:subtitle: A huge fire has ravaged the Moria facility on the island of Lesbos
item.itunes:summary: A huge fire has ravaged the Moria facility on the island of Lesbos. Thousands of migrants have been left homeless. Also, efforts to make the Oscars more diverse, and how one man developed a friendship with an octopus.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: US protests: Rochester police leaders resign en masse
item.description: Pressure is growing in Rochester over the death of a black man named Daniel Prude, who asphyxiated after being restrained by police. Also, Italy’s fashion industry grapples with racism. And, how will taking photos of broccoli today help scientists study space tomorrow?
item.itunes:subtitle: A black man, Daniel Prude, died after an interaction with Rochester police this year
item.itunes:summary: Pressure is growing in Rochester over the death of a black man named Daniel Prude, who asphyxiated after being restrained by police. Also, Italy’s fashion industry grapples with racism. And, how will taking photos of broccoli today help scientists study space tomorrow?
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Belarus: Lukashenko admits being in power too long
item.description: The long term leader has told Russian media he won't be stepping down despite weeks of protests. Meanwhile Belarus opposition leader resists deportation. Also: the floods threatening Sudan's ancient ruins, and why Senegal has been praised for its handling of the coronavirus.
item.itunes:subtitle: The long term leader has told Russian media he won't be stepping down
item.itunes:summary: The long term leader has told Russian media he won't be stepping down despite weeks of protests. Meanwhile Belarus opposition leader resists deportation. Also: the floods threatening Sudan's ancient ruins, and why Senegal has been praised for its handling of the coronavirus.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Russia's Alexei Navalny out of coma after poisoning
item.description: Doctors treating Russian opposition figure Alexei Navalny say he is out of an induced coma and his condition, since being poisoned, has improved. Also: A Saudi court commutes the death sentences of those convicted of murdering the journalist Jamal Khashoggi, and Afghan officials and the Taliban prepare for formal talks in Qatar.
item.itunes:subtitle: German doctors treating the opposition figure in Berlin say his health has improved
item.itunes:summary: Doctors treating Russian opposition figure Alexei Navalny say he is out of an induced coma and his condition, since being poisoned, has improved. Also: A Saudi court commutes the death sentences of those convicted of murdering the journalist Jamal Khashoggi, and Afghan officials and the Taliban prepare for formal talks in Qatar.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Belarus opposition leader reportedly abducted
item.description: Witnesses say Maria Kolesnikova was bundled into a minibus by masked men and driven away. Also: WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange appears in a London court to fight a US extradition request, and Nigerian doctors go on strike.
item.itunes:subtitle: Witnesses say Maria Kolesnikova was bundled into a minibus by masked men and driven away
item.itunes:summary: Witnesses say Maria Kolesnikova was bundled into a minibus by masked men and driven away. Also: WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange appears in a London court to fight a US extradition request, and Nigerian doctors go on strike.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Belarus: Protesters gather for the fourth week in a row
item.description: More than 100,000 anti-government demonstrators took to the streets in Minsk. Also: India now has the second highest number of coronavirus cases in the world, and Jacob Blake sends his first public message from a hospital bed.
item.itunes:subtitle: More than 100,000 anti-government demonstrators took to the streets in Minsk
item.itunes:summary: More than 100,000 anti-government demonstrators took to the streets in Minsk. Also: India now has the second highest number of coronavirus cases in the world, and Jacob Blake sends his first public message from a hospital bed.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Rohingya refugees: Bangladesh plans to move thousands to an island
item.description: Many refugees are reluctant to move to Bhashan Char island, even if it means leaving the crowded camps where they now live. Also, soldiers in Niger are accused of executing dozens of civilians earlier this year. And India introduces coronavirus tests on demand, as its outbreak surges.
item.itunes:subtitle: Human rights activists say Bhashan Char island is prone to monsoons
item.itunes:summary: Many refugees are reluctant to move to Bhashan Char island, even if it means leaving the crowded camps where they now live. Also, soldiers in Niger are accused of executing dozens of civilians earlier this year. And India introduces coronavirus tests on demand, as its outbreak surges.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: US unemployment falls again - good news for Trump?
item.description: US unemployment rate below 10% for the first time since the beginning of the pandemic, also:Iran breached limits of nuclear agreement says UN watchdog and Messi stays with Barça
item.itunes:subtitle: US unemployment rate below 10% for the first time since the beginning of the pandemic
item.itunes:summary: US unemployment rate below 10% for the first time since the beginning of the pandemic, also:Iran breached limits of nuclear agreement says UN watchdog and Messi stays with Barça
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Islamic State: Giant library of group's online propaganda discovered
item.description: Researchers find one of largest collections of IS online material. Experts say it enables group to continually replenish extremist content on the net. Also, Dutch far-Right politician Geert Wilders cleared of inciting hatred, and US academic says she lied about being black.
item.itunes:subtitle: Researchers find one of largest collections of IS online material
item.itunes:summary: Researchers find one of largest collections of IS online material. Experts say it enables group to continually replenish extremist content on the net. Also, Dutch far-Right politician Geert Wilders cleared of inciting hatred, and US academic says she lied about being black.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Biden speaks to Jacob Blake on Wisconsin visit
item.description: The US Democratic presidential candidate, Joe Biden, says the shooting victim told him he "won't give up". Also: Beirut rescuers investigate signs of life in rubble, and English Premier League terminates huge China TV rights deal.
item.itunes:subtitle: President Trump visited Kenosha on Tuesday
item.itunes:summary: The US Democratic presidential candidate, Joe Biden, says the shooting victim told him he "won't give up". Also: Beirut rescuers investigate signs of life in rubble, and English Premier League terminates huge China TV rights deal.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Tycoon cleared of murders that rocked Slovakia
item.description: The killing of the investigative journalist, Jan Kuciak, and his fiancée in 2018 led to protests and the collapse of the government. Also: President Trump tells voters in North Carolina to vote twice to test the system, and Brazil's men and women international football players get equal pay.
item.itunes:subtitle: The killing of a journalist in 2018 led to collapse of government
item.itunes:summary: The killing of the investigative journalist, Jan Kuciak, and his fiancée in 2018 led to protests and the collapse of the government. Also: President Trump tells voters in North Carolina to vote twice to test the system, and Brazil's men and women international football players get equal pay.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Russia's Navalny 'poisoned with Novichok'
item.description: The German chancellor Angela Merkel says Alexei Navalny was a victim of attempted murder. Also: US sanctions staff at top war crimes court, and Prince Harry and Meghan to make shows with Netflix.
item.itunes:subtitle: Alexei Navalny remains in a coma in a Berlin hospital
item.itunes:summary: The German chancellor Angela Merkel says Alexei Navalny was a victim of attempted murder. Also: US sanctions staff at top war crimes court, and Prince Harry and Meghan to make shows with Netflix.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Charlie Hebdo: 14 suspects on trial over deadly Paris attacks
item.description: Suspects are accused of helping radical Islamists who killed 12 people in January 2015. Most of alleged accomplices are in court in Paris but 3 are being tried in absentia. Also, scepticism in Lebanon about official investigation into Beirut blast, and how Earth is rattled after 7 billion years by signals from black holes' collision.
item.itunes:subtitle: Suspects are accused of helping radical Islamists who killed 12 people in January 2015
item.itunes:summary: Suspects are accused of helping radical Islamists who killed 12 people in January 2015. Most of alleged accomplices are in court in Paris but 3 are being tried in absentia. Also, scepticism in Lebanon about official investigation into Beirut blast, and how Earth is rattled after 7 billion years by signals from black holes' collision.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Trump visits Kenosha to back police after shooting
item.description: The US president blames what he calls "domestic terror" for the "destruction" in the Midwestern city. Also: Zimbabwe to return farmland seized from foreigners; and with a changing world, Dictionary.com changes its definitions of many words.
item.itunes:subtitle: Kenosha saw days of violence after police shot Jacob Blake
item.itunes:summary: The US president blames what he calls "domestic terror" for the "destruction" in the Midwestern city. Also: Zimbabwe to return farmland seized from foreigners; and with a changing world, Dictionary.com changes its definitions of many words.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Charlie Hebdo magazine republishes Mohammed cartoons
item.description: Alleged accomplices to the deadly attack on the magazine go on trial on Wednesday. Twelve people were killed in 2015 including famous cartoonists. Also: students in Belarus protest against President Lukashenko on the first day of the university term. And, K-Pop conquers the US charts.
item.itunes:subtitle: Alleged accomplices to the deadly attack on the magazine go on trial on Wednesday
item.itunes:summary: Alleged accomplices to the deadly attack on the magazine go on trial on Wednesday. Twelve people were killed in 2015 including famous cartoonists. Also: students in Belarus protest against President Lukashenko on the first day of the university term. And, K-Pop conquers the US charts.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: US election: Biden accuses 'weak' Trump of stoking violence
item.description: The Democratic Party's candidate for the US presidency Joe Biden has challenged President Trump on law and order, asking voters if they feel safe with a leader who can’t control his supporters. Also: Australia says China has detained a prominent journalist without charge, and new figures show the Indian economy has been devastated by the pandemic.
item.itunes:subtitle: Mr Trump has made "law and order" a major theme of his campaign
item.itunes:summary: The Democratic Party's candidate for the US presidency Joe Biden has challenged President Trump on law and order, asking voters if they feel safe with a leader who can’t control his supporters. Also: Australia says China has detained a prominent journalist without charge, and new figures show the Indian economy has been devastated by the pandemic.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Global News Brexitcast
item.description: We team up with the award-winning Brexitcast team to bring you a special update on what Britain leaving the EU means for you. You’ve sent us questions from around the world and Jackie Leonard puts them to the experts from the podcast that’s all about Brexit. There’s also cake, phew. Spread the word! #GlobalNewsPod #Brexitcast Find the Brexitcast podcast here: http://www.bbc.co.uk/brexitcast
item.itunes:subtitle: What will Brexit mean for you? We team up with Brexitcast to bring you the answers
